description: This exam has been retired. CompTIA and the Linux Professional Institute (LPI) have worked in conjunction to create the CompTIA Linux+ certification. The certification covers the basic knowledge required of a junior level Linux administrator. Candidates are expected to be able to work competently across a wide array of environments and skill sets. Unlike many certifications, candidates who complete the Linux+ exams (LX0-101 and LX0-102) are awarded with not one, but two certifications: the CompTIA Linux+ certification and the LPI LPIC-1 certification. That makes this an excellent starting point for people interested in working with Linux as you gain essential base knowledge as well as fill out your resume.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.900
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.286 --> 00:00:08.950
All right.

3
00:00:08.950 --> 00:00:13.340
Today we're gonna take a look at
the Linux+ certification from CompTIA.

4
00:00:13.340 --> 00:00:16.110
This is kind of an interesting
certification compared to

5
00:00:16.110 --> 00:00:17.940
a lot of the ones that CompTIA does,

6
00:00:17.940 --> 00:00:22.160
because it's the first one that
they didn't actually develop.

7
00:00:22.160 --> 00:00:24.820
And so that makes it interesting,
so we do wanna talk about it.

8
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:29.570
Kinda what it is, what it covers, and
why CompTIA didn't develop this exam.

9
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:31.270
It's all important stuff to know,

10
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:35.170
so let's just start with
the basics with what is Linux+?

11
00:00:35.170 --> 00:00:37.780
It's a certification from CompTIA,

12
00:00:37.780 --> 00:00:42.590
the same people that bring you A+,
Net+, Security+, they bring you Linux+.

13
00:00:42.590 --> 00:00:46.770
And it's designed to show that
a network or systems administrator

14
00:00:46.770 --> 00:00:51.760
has a basic level of knowledge in
operating Linux servers and workstations.

15
00:00:51.760 --> 00:00:55.760
It's designed to be vendor neutral so
it's not Red Hat only or

16
00:00:55.760 --> 00:00:57.670
Ubuntu canonical, whatever.

17
00:00:57.670 --> 00:01:00.690
It is design to be vendor neutral but

18
00:01:00.690 --> 00:01:04.660
it does actually focus a little bit on
the Red Hat-based Linux products and

19
00:01:04.660 --> 00:01:08.080
the Debian-based Linux products,
which almost everything is these days.

20
00:01:08.080 --> 00:01:11.635
So it does a great job of straddling
the fence between those and

21
00:01:11.635 --> 00:01:16.025
showing concepts, commands,
administration tools and

22
00:01:16.025 --> 00:01:20.980
techniques that apply to both sets of the
Linux distributions that are out there.

23
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:26.210
So it is a great certification in that it
does show you have that general knowledge.

24
00:01:26.210 --> 00:01:27.180
Now, in the beginning,

25
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:32.250
CompTIA actually had their own in-house
developed Linux+ certification.

26
00:01:32.250 --> 00:01:35.000
But over time,
they wanted to make it better and

27
00:01:35.000 --> 00:01:37.270
more generally accepted
amongst the community.

28
00:01:37.270 --> 00:01:40.150
So instead of continuing to
write the exam themselves,

29
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:44.810
they partnered with the LPI,
the Linux Professional Institute.

30
00:01:44.810 --> 00:01:49.850
LPI actually had, or has, four levels
of Linux certification available,

31
00:01:49.850 --> 00:01:52.780
from basic all the way up to
super mega expert, right?

32
00:01:52.780 --> 00:01:55.511
You have to wear suspenders and
have a beard for that one.

33
00:01:55.511 --> 00:01:57.265
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Even if you're a woman.

34
00:01:57.265 --> 00:02:02.260
[LAUGH] And so you know they've
got some really advanced stuff and

35
00:02:02.260 --> 00:02:05.640
CompTIA said well you know,
we really just want the lower end, right?

36
00:02:05.640 --> 00:02:08.025
The introductories,
people have the base knowledge,

37
00:02:08.025 --> 00:02:11.330
it's the equivalent of one year of
field experience working with Linux.

38
00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:15.320
That's what they're shooting for
and the LPI said well great.

39
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:19.910
What you can do is you can use our first
two exams for our certification track and

40
00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:24.460
use that to gauge your Linux+ testers,
right?

41
00:02:24.460 --> 00:02:25.910
And so that's what they did,
they partnered up,

42
00:02:25.910 --> 00:02:28.880
it's been a great partnership
between the two organizations.

43
00:02:28.880 --> 00:02:31.850
And so when you look at the CompTIA
webpages, it'll always say,

44
00:02:31.850 --> 00:02:33.859
well look I've got it
pulled up right here.

45
00:02:33.859 --> 00:02:38.612
CompTIA Linux+ Powered by LPI, and
that lets you know that while it is

46
00:02:38.612 --> 00:02:43.580
a CompTIA certification,
it's actually developed by the LPI.

47
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:44.700
On a neat side,

48
00:02:44.700 --> 00:02:48.730
it means when you pass the exams,
you actually get two certifications.

49
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:53.360
You get the CompTIA Linux+ which
is what most of us are after.

50
00:02:53.360 --> 00:02:58.120
And then on the LPI,
Linux Professional Institute, side,

51
00:02:58.120 --> 00:03:02.850
you'll see that you actually end up with
what's called their LPIC-1 certification,

52
00:03:02.850 --> 00:03:05.160
Junior Level Linux certification.

53
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:08.640
And to get that you have to
pass their first two exams

54
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:11.330
which are the same exams you
have to take for Linux+.

55
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:14.200
So you actually end up double
certified which is just kind of neat.

56
00:03:15.360 --> 00:03:19.910
Now, CompTIA does stop there at Linux+,
they don't go beyond that.

57
00:03:19.910 --> 00:03:22.670
And so if you want to get
more advanced Linux skills,

58
00:03:22.670 --> 00:03:26.290
well that's where you come over to LPI and
you do LPIC-2, LPIC-3, right?

59
00:03:26.290 --> 00:03:30.150
That's how that partnership works, and how
both companies benefit from it and how you

60
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:35.250
benefit from it too, because I'll tell
you a lot of people have heard of Linux+.

61
00:03:35.250 --> 00:03:40.339
It's a very popular certification, not
as many people have heard of LPIC-2 and

62
00:03:40.339 --> 00:03:41.088
LPIC-3.

63
00:03:41.088 --> 00:03:45.590
They're great certifications, believe me,
but not as many people have heard of them.

64
00:03:45.590 --> 00:03:48.430
If you want advanced certifications,
they're the way to go, right?

65
00:03:48.430 --> 00:03:51.080
But if you're just trying to do that
entry-level thing, something that's higher

66
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:54.000
visibility is great,
looks great on the resume, so here you go.

67
00:03:55.410 --> 00:03:59.140
All right, now the Linux+ certification
is actually broken up into two exams.

68
00:03:59.140 --> 00:04:00.058
So, we have.

69
00:04:00.058 --> 00:04:01.797
Actually do they show it on this page?

70
00:04:01.797 --> 00:04:06.525
There it is, the LX0-101 and the LX0-102,

71
00:04:06.525 --> 00:04:10.030
two different certification exams.

72
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:15.195
They are a little bit on the pricey side,
as most CompTIA exams have been lately,

73
00:04:15.195 --> 00:04:18.140
they've kind of raised
a bunch of their prices.

74
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:21.140
But it's right around
180 dollars per exam.

75
00:04:21.140 --> 00:04:24.095
Obviously, it varies based on your country
but it's right around in that area.

76
00:04:24.095 --> 00:04:29.248
So to take both of them you
are looking at almost 400 dollars,

77
00:04:29.248 --> 00:04:34.180
US dollars, so it can be a little
bit pricey, but it is two exams.

78
00:04:34.180 --> 00:04:38.370
90 minutes each, so they're not incredibly
long, but you'll have 60 questions so

79
00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:41.190
that means you get about a minute and
a half per question and

80
00:04:41.190 --> 00:04:43.120
you don't wanna dabble too much.

81
00:04:43.120 --> 00:04:44.780
They are mostly multiple choice,

82
00:04:44.780 --> 00:04:48.750
there have been rumors of simulation
questions making it on the exams.

83
00:04:48.750 --> 00:04:53.550
I haven't seen that yet but the rumor's
out there, so it's mostly multiple choice,

84
00:04:53.550 --> 00:04:55.560
and you can take it in
several different languages.

85
00:04:55.560 --> 00:05:00.220
Like all CompTIA exams,
they're administered through Pearson VUE.

86
00:05:00.220 --> 00:05:04.260
So you just find the local VUE
testing center that is near you.

87
00:05:04.260 --> 00:05:10.102
If you're not familiar with VUE,
their website is pearsonvue, it's V-U-E,

88
00:05:10.102 --> 00:05:15.170
.com and they have testing
locations all over the world.

89
00:05:15.170 --> 00:05:20.010
So you just come in here and you say,
test taker services, you're trying to take

90
00:05:20.010 --> 00:05:23.365
a test and you'll come in and pick what
you're trying to get certified in.

91
00:05:23.365 --> 00:05:29.485
So we can go to IT and
find old CompTIA in here, there we go.

92
00:05:29.485 --> 00:05:31.005
And once we're in here.

93
00:05:31.005 --> 00:05:33.432
Nice, thank you for
telling me about your cookies.

94
00:05:33.432 --> 00:05:36.607
[LAUGH] So you can come in here, and you
can kinda figure out what it is you want.

95
00:05:36.607 --> 00:05:39.227
And you've got locate a test center, and

96
00:05:39.227 --> 00:05:43.207
we can find the test center that is
near us based on wherever it is you are.

97
00:05:43.207 --> 00:05:47.097
So maybe you are in Paris, France,
so I'll just punch that in.

98
00:05:48.957 --> 00:05:55.477
And looks like we got a couple there,
depending on which you are in.

99
00:05:55.477 --> 00:05:57.337
See, I'll show off my
witty Parisian knowledge.

100
00:05:57.337 --> 00:05:58.242
>> That's nice, yes.

101
00:05:58.242 --> 00:06:00.170
So, anyhow you can see some
of the different places

102
00:06:00.170 --> 00:06:01.330
that are available to test there.

103
00:06:01.330 --> 00:06:02.290
All over the world.

104
00:06:02.290 --> 00:06:05.464
I think we have 2 of them here in our
town, and our town is a pretty small one.

105
00:06:05.464 --> 00:06:08.908
So you can go and take the test there,
it's pretty low pressure, right?

106
00:06:08.908 --> 00:06:14.680
60 questions, 90 minutes, multiple choice,
it's not so bad if you know your stuff.

107
00:06:14.680 --> 00:06:17.215
So what is the stuff that we need to know?

108
00:06:17.215 --> 00:06:20.430
Well the two exams
are a little bit different.

109
00:06:20.430 --> 00:06:25.890
We've got the LX0-101,
that's the first exam, and

110
00:06:25.890 --> 00:06:30.250
it covers what I consider to be
the introductory information.

111
00:06:30.250 --> 00:06:32.930
Now if you've never
worked with Linux before,

112
00:06:32.930 --> 00:06:34.670
some of this is pretty challenging.

113
00:06:34.670 --> 00:06:36.200
But if you've got experience with Linux,

114
00:06:36.200 --> 00:06:39.800
if you've been running it on your desktop
or as a server for years and years.

115
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:44.370
This one's actually the easier of the two
exams because it's covering things like

116
00:06:44.370 --> 00:06:46.660
how to get Linux installed.

117
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:51.935
So, just installing it on a computer, how
to get it updated to make sure that you're

118
00:06:51.935 --> 00:06:57.110
doing hot fixes and security updates, it's
covering basic command line exercises.

119
00:06:57.110 --> 00:06:59.250
Now that's really important.

120
00:06:59.250 --> 00:07:03.000
A lot of people say, well,
I've been running Linux for five years and

121
00:07:03.000 --> 00:07:05.380
I use Ubuntu and I love it, right?

122
00:07:05.380 --> 00:07:08.140
And then I say okay how often do you drop

123
00:07:08.140 --> 00:07:10.550
to the terminal shell to
actually run command line?

124
00:07:10.550 --> 00:07:13.890
And they go well never,
I do it all through the GUI.

125
00:07:13.890 --> 00:07:16.340
Well that's a recipe for disaster, right?

126
00:07:16.340 --> 00:07:18.640
Because the GUI differs so

127
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:24.150
much from distro to distro, it's hard
to learn one way that works everywhere.

128
00:07:24.150 --> 00:07:27.305
And if you're on a server you
shouldn't have a GUI at all.

129
00:07:27.305 --> 00:07:32.750
Right, so the exam is almost
entirely based on command line.

130
00:07:32.750 --> 00:07:36.957
Cuz when you learn something that way,
when you learn it command line style,

131
00:07:36.957 --> 00:07:39.442
you can use it on any
GNU Linux distribution.

132
00:07:39.442 --> 00:07:44.850
And so that really makes life easy,
standard, compliant, right?

133
00:07:44.850 --> 00:07:47.670
So if you've got a lot of graphical
user interface experience,

134
00:07:47.670 --> 00:07:50.700
that will help you a little bit on
the second exam, but on the first exam,

135
00:07:50.700 --> 00:07:52.780
you're gonna be dead in the water,
cuz it's almost all command line.

136
00:07:52.780 --> 00:07:56.840
So we tackle that,
the GNU and Unix commands.

137
00:07:56.840 --> 00:08:00.490
We also take a look at how
hardware devices are accessed,

138
00:08:00.490 --> 00:08:05.390
how the file systems work, and the file
hierarchy, how the folders are arranged.

139
00:08:05.390 --> 00:08:08.190
And again, if you've been
working with Unix or Linux for

140
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:12.370
a while, then that's second
nature by now more than likely.

141
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:14.100
But, if you're brand new to this,

142
00:08:14.100 --> 00:08:17.690
it's really different than a lot of other
operating systems that are out there.

143
00:08:17.690 --> 00:08:20.970
If you've got a lot of Windows experience,
this stuff will blow your mind,

144
00:08:20.970 --> 00:08:22.690
because it's really different,

145
00:08:22.690 --> 00:08:27.230
that hardware devices reference as files,
not as objects.

146
00:08:27.230 --> 00:08:30.621
If you're used to OSX and Mac OS,

147
00:08:30.621 --> 00:08:34.070
Mac OS is running on top of BSD so
you might think they're similar.

148
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:38.610
But Apple is tweaked with that file system
so much that directories and paths and

149
00:08:38.610 --> 00:08:42.250
stuff are just not the same
as we see in the Linux world.

150
00:08:42.250 --> 00:08:45.130
So getting used to this can be
a little challenging, right, so

151
00:08:45.130 --> 00:08:46.270
definitely keep that in mind.

152
00:08:47.810 --> 00:08:50.030
So that's kind of what you
expect to see on the first exam.

153
00:08:50.030 --> 00:08:56.490
Notice that the bulk of it, 43% of that
exam, is from the command line, right.

154
00:08:56.490 --> 00:09:02.250
GNU and Unix, or GNU, sometimes called
New, in Unix command line utility.

155
00:09:02.250 --> 00:09:05.120
So, you've really got to
spend some time on that.

156
00:09:05.120 --> 00:09:09.750
If you are, [LAUGH] if you're
30 plus years old and you cut

157
00:09:09.750 --> 00:09:14.650
your teeth on DOS and Windows 3.1, then
it's not a big challenge to pick that up.

158
00:09:14.650 --> 00:09:19.940
But if you're 20 years old and just out
of high school and you grew up with

159
00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:24.130
Windows XP and stuff, you might not
have used the command line very much.

160
00:09:24.130 --> 00:09:27.389
And even if you've been in
the Linux world for 10,

161
00:09:27.389 --> 00:09:30.990
20 years, you might be GUI-heavy and
not command line-heavy.

162
00:09:30.990 --> 00:09:34.110
So, we do need to make sure we focus
in on that and spend some time.

163
00:09:34.110 --> 00:09:36.480
That's what you're gonna
see on the first exam.

164
00:09:36.480 --> 00:09:38.920
So basic operational skills and really,

165
00:09:38.920 --> 00:09:43.120
everything that you learn in this exam
should apply to any Linux distribution

166
00:09:43.120 --> 00:09:46.982
that you're running unless it's some
crazy completely whacked out one.

167
00:09:46.982 --> 00:09:49.269
[LAUGH] But
most of them will work just like this.

168
00:09:50.660 --> 00:09:51.327
All right,

169
00:09:51.327 --> 00:09:55.270
now each of these topics are broken
down into quite a bit of sub topics.

170
00:09:55.270 --> 00:09:58.140
You'll see some of the different things
that it goes into and we'll go over all

171
00:09:58.140 --> 00:10:01.320
these during the actual show so I don't
want to bore us to death with them now.

172
00:10:01.320 --> 00:10:03.280
But lets take a look at that second exam.

173
00:10:03.280 --> 00:10:06.800
The other exam is the LX0-102,

174
00:10:06.800 --> 00:10:11.840
this guy right here, and it breaks
things down a little bit differently.

175
00:10:11.840 --> 00:10:15.860
You'll see where we tackle Shells,
Scripting and Data Management, all right?

176
00:10:17.230 --> 00:10:20.890
In my opinion, scripting is one of
the most useful things that you can learn,

177
00:10:20.890 --> 00:10:22.920
because you don't wanna
run the same task over and

178
00:10:22.920 --> 00:10:26.300
over again if you can automate it, and
scripting is all about automating it.

179
00:10:26.300 --> 00:10:27.830
So we're gonna get
a chance to see that and

180
00:10:27.830 --> 00:10:30.770
as an administrator that's something
we really do benefit from.

181
00:10:30.770 --> 00:10:35.340
We'll see user interfaces and desktops,
we're gonna talk about several of

182
00:10:35.340 --> 00:10:39.930
the different graphical user interfaces
available because you've got Gnome and

183
00:10:39.930 --> 00:10:44.665
KDE, you've got Enlightenment,
I think ten people run that.

184
00:10:44.665 --> 00:10:46.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Xfce, which is one of my favorites,

185
00:10:46.870 --> 00:10:49.940
so there's several different user
interfaces that are out there,

186
00:10:49.940 --> 00:10:52.810
we'll take a look at each of them and
some of the ins and outs.

187
00:10:52.810 --> 00:10:57.565
But notice, user interfaces and
desktops, only 8%,

188
00:10:57.565 --> 00:11:02.665
very small part of that exam because
it's just not standard between systems.

189
00:11:02.665 --> 00:11:06.435
We'll see general administrative tasks,
things like creating user accounts,

190
00:11:06.435 --> 00:11:09.600
changing file permissions,
stuff like that.

191
00:11:09.600 --> 00:11:14.200
Essential system services, we'll take a
look at web servers and e-mail servers and

192
00:11:14.200 --> 00:11:16.520
some of the things that we typically run.

193
00:11:16.520 --> 00:11:20.290
We'll definitely spend some time on SSH
cuz that's such an important service and

194
00:11:20.290 --> 00:11:24.290
a few of the other services that we
may use as a part of running Linux.

195
00:11:25.300 --> 00:11:27.890
We've got networking fundamentals.

196
00:11:27.890 --> 00:11:31.800
So configuring our network adapter, some
of the neat features we have in Linux,

197
00:11:31.800 --> 00:11:35.560
IPv4 and IPv6 support,
some of the different things there.

198
00:11:35.560 --> 00:11:39.830
As well as NFS, the network file system,
we’ll cover it in there too.

199
00:11:39.830 --> 00:11:43.250
And then lastly, security,
it’s last but not least.

200
00:11:43.250 --> 00:11:46.370
In a very literal sense,
security is really important to us.

201
00:11:46.370 --> 00:11:50.710
A lot of us are using Linux as a server
operating system and in that scenario,

202
00:11:50.710 --> 00:11:53.970
security's really important so
we need to take a look at that.

203
00:11:53.970 --> 00:11:57.930
We're gonna take a look at configuring
software firewalls under Linux, as well as

204
00:11:57.930 --> 00:12:01.990
other processes like just staying up to
date that are really, really important.

205
00:12:03.020 --> 00:12:05.730
So, the first exam is based on

206
00:12:05.730 --> 00:12:09.170
fundamentals that every Linux
administrator should have.

207
00:12:09.170 --> 00:12:12.660
The second exam is based
more on practical skills,

208
00:12:12.660 --> 00:12:15.570
things we're gonna do on
an ongoing day-to-day basis.

209
00:12:15.570 --> 00:12:19.160
So they're really two neat

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Don demonstrate and discuss how to obtain a copy of Debian and install it. Debian is one of the major distro branch that other Linux distros are based. They guide a user with no previous Linux experience on the installation process and what options are available on during the installation. They also show that the basic installation involves the use of the command-line utilities: apt-get, ifconfig and basic navigation commands that Linux Admins should readily use.
episodes.title: Installing Linux Part 1

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don demonstrate and discuss how to obtain a copy of CentOS and install it. CentOS is used in place of Red Hat Enterprise. They guide a user with no previous Linux experience on the installation process and what options are available on during the installation. They also show that the basic installation involves the use of the command-line utilities: yum, ifconfig and basic navigation commands that Linux Admins should readily use.
episodes.title: Installing Linux Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss the use of file editors. They list several of the different file editors and talk about their availability among different distros. The demonstrate the use of vi, the file editor that is found in just about every distro available. They show the power of vi to create a file, modify and save a file. They discuss the use of vi directly, on a consoled connection and a remote connection as well. They go through the basic commands that every Linux Admin needs to know when using a file editor.
episodes.title: Command Line Interface

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into working with the Command Line Interface of CentOS. They show basic tasks that could be accomplished in the GUI can also be accomplished by using Linux CLI shell commands. They demonstrate some file output commands and the use of filtering to easily manage what is displayed. They spend some time performing basic file management tasks and computer management task.
episodes.title: Command Line Interface Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don are connecting hardware devices to our Linux distro for usage. They spend some time also taking a deeper look into the boot sequence, boot loader and the boot events that happens prior to and during the installation process.
episodes.title: System Architecture

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Don tackle the concept of file systems and partition management from the Linux CLI. They talk about the various options available to Linux. They create a partition format it for use in Linux. Also they show how to mount and unmount a file system.
episodes.title: Disk Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don reinstall a CentOS distribution for the purpose of choosing no default options on the installation regarding Hard Disk configurations from the CLI. They also show the default system files hierarchy created and describe what file hierarchy system is created when you install a Linux distro.
episodes.title: Disk Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at maintaining the hard disk from the CLI by creating disk quotas and managing permissions. They show how to see the integrity of the file systems and monitor disk usage. The talk about the use of symbolic and hard links.
episodes.title: Disk Management Part 3

topics.title: Devices, Linux Filesystems, Filesystem Hierarchy Standard

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don configure a customized shell environment and demonstrate how do create a default shell environment for all users or configure it for individuals. Within the shell environment, they also set the search path for running applications. They show the creation of a script to add users to the system and end the episode by installing a MySQL server and running simple data manipulation commands against a database.
episodes.title: Shells and Scripting

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Don install the GUI options to the CLI environment and configure X Window options. With the GUI installed, they setup the display manager and show how to configure it for users. They also walk through the accessibility options available for people with impaired abilities.
episodes.title: Graphical User Interface

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don tackle Linux administrative tasks through the CLI. These tasks include managing user and group accounts and the password database. They take a look at setting up scheduled tasks using cron jobs and the 'at' command. Because Linux Systems may be located and relocated to different places in the world, they show the locale and time zone settings. They also talk about the importance of time synchronization for computer systems and how to configure NTP.
episodes.title: Administrative Tasks

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Don dive into Linux System Services and show configuring system logging and using the basic Mail Transfer Agent within the Linux distro through the CLI. They also configure the use of printers and manage printing through the CLI.
episodes.title: Essential System Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don go through the basic networking fundamentals and basic CLI tools used in troubleshooting. They also show how to configure basic networking manually using the multiple files that must be used when setting up basic networking for the Linux System.
episodes.title: Networking

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Don guide us through setting up security for the Linux Server that is to be used in production networks. They show how to change passwords, set up auditing and using proper security procedures. They setup basic host security. Also in this episode, they configure SSH for securing data on Linux Systems.
episodes.title: Security Administration
